ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The lectures were very clear and engaging, and I enjoyed discovering links between the fundamental physiology taught in the first half and the applications of the theory in the second half. Demonstrations of actual methods were great and I would have loved more hands-on or outdoor activities.
This course was a great mix between lecture and discussion. I like that it was a small class, because that allowed for interaction between students
Reading and discussing scientific literature.

This course opened my eyes to w whole field of science I never knew. The instructor was conducting ground-breaking experiments in the field and kept us very up-to-date with the field. I really appreciated how the instructor was concerned that we students learned important things from this class and cared about the subject. Certain professors, such as Dana Tomlin, could learn tremendously from this young professor's interest in his students and care for FES in general. Also, the teaching assistant was great. I would recommend this class to anyone interested in plants.
The combination of fundamentals and applied, particularly as explicitly interesting to the class!

The structure of the class in the first half of the semester was very conducive to learning. I liked how class started out with a lecture or powerpoint and then transitioned into discussion of the readings. The hands-on part of the class was also very helpful to understand how many of the studies we read about later in the class were conducted.
Class time outside with tools was great!

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: More structure/background to contextualize the readings in the second half of the course - it was good practice for students to lead class, but those discussions also ended up being less focused.
I liked it as is

Prof. Brodersen needs to speak up; he swallows his words sometimes, making it difficult to follow. Also, the course could use a little more background about the field and plant biology before diving into the complex materials to be studied. The format of the course was strained a bit in the second half of the semester. We were to present several dry scientific papers for a several hour class period. Ideally this type of class should facilitate discussion, but we really needed more instructor leadership in facilitating the conversation.

I think that there were plant terminology basics (as opposed to just water basics) that it would've been useful to review. Maybe just give us some of the extra intro material with plant parts etc that you use in the undergrad course?

A crash course in plant physiology would be very helpful in the beginning of the semester. It could be an extra session held by the TA. The second half of the semester (the student lead discussion sections) were not always helpful. Three hours is a long time for students to lead a discussion on very technical research papers.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: This course had no labs, but it should have.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This course fits very well within my larger program.
This course provided valuable groundwork to all plant study.
Incredibly helpful complementary information for my ecological study; gives a very useful framework, endlessly applicable!
This course fits very nicely into my program. Having an understanding of plant hydraulics is necessary for my future career.
Good overview of plant and tree anatomy as it relates to water flow. I liked scaling up from individual tree to larger scale drought and water issues in forest.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I am interested in how water moves through plants
Met a requirement, and the teacher seemed nice.

trees are magnificent! FES needs more hardcore plant science classes! Basic plant physiological understanding is crucial for all scientists, managers, and policy-makers! Courses like this should more of a priority in the FES curriculum overall!
Not only was this course a requirement for my program, it was also of great interest to me. It was a topic that I was not very knowledgable about and I knew that I needed to take the class.
To fulfill science requirement for MF degree.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: I had heard this would be a great course, and it was!
Yes
It exceeded by expectations.
absolutely
Yes, I definitely learned a lot from this course. I am sure that I'll be applying what I learned from this class to my future studies and career.
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: We led a discussion in pairs, and it was nice to be able to partner with a fellow student
I got to see how a classmate thinks and works, and we both came through with the assignment during a difficult time of the semester. I'm better friends with this person now.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: This is a great opportunity to learn cutting-edge plant physiology and also find out how those ideas can be applied to ecology and conservation. Really interesting if you're at all excited about understanding how plants work.
Don't be intimidated.

If you have a strong interest in understanding how trees function, this course is a must! I strongly encourage any MF or MFS students to take this course if they have not already taken a similar course already.
